I live in a multi-story building with an outer security door. So can these robots come up the stairs, ring my unit, wait for the door to be unlocked, open the door by pulling it outwards, come into the foyer, ring for the elevator, pick the correct floor, and then find my unit and knock on the door? Because...that is what i'm used to for deliveries. I see this a good R&D project to push forward technology, but practically speaking, the chances for this technology to put delivery people out of work...is nil. Just too many ways for this to fail (theft, kids knocking it over, electro-mechanical fail, and general public safety (e.g. knocks over old lady) or gets dog poop on wheel and then spreads it around. Not to mention weather.

FedEx was the only one whose speed came close to delivering ice cream (or pizza). It handled terrain the best. If a delivery boy traveled the speed those bots traveled, he would be fired. Any distance longer than 300 to 500 feet will be a problem. They need to travel with traffic, or ride a mother ship that can. Customers can walk to the store faster. People want deliveries when the weather and/or traffic is bad. That means freezing rain on doors and moving parts, pushing and balancing on snow, many icy roads, sidewalks, and slopes, and extreme cold (batteries), not to mention cracked asphalt, potholes, and broken concrete. Pizza delivery people supply their car and gas. These expensive robots will require a business to purchase at least one, if not a fleet.

I live in Seattle. For the past 10 years we have been dealing with an increase in homelessness, created by the cost of living, the lack of mental health/social services support, and government inaction. One side effect of this has been the increase in crime and vandalism in the downtown core. Scooter and bike rentals have suffered from theft and repurposed assets by the "unhoused", and I would anticipate these robots would be even more vulnerable to predation given the easy access to goods being delivered. I wish this were not the case, as this is a legitimate way to reduce traffic and automate mundane work.

In my area, the vast majority of fast food deliveries are done by bike, some by electric bikes or electric scooters. These robots would, therefore, achieve one thing, unemployment. They also need to travel more slowly than a human on a bike, so food would not be as warm when it arrived. Some have commented on using these to deliver packages. Is it really a good idea to replace 1 driver in 1 car, who can be making 20 to 30 deliveries, with a greater number of these? I have my groceries delivered, the van drivers tell me that they make 8 to 10 deliveries per trip, and during a day will do 4 or 5 trips. These robots would need to be larger, divided into compartments with a chilled section and a frozen section, and a large number of units would be required to fulfil current demand. Even if roadways could, eventually, be reclaimed to provide more space for pedestrians, there would not be enough space for robots and people, especially as reclaimed roadways usually include space for bikes. There are many issues raised by this type of system: •Rural areas are not catered for. •In a CBD or an urban area with high rise accommodation, how do the robots access upper floors? If they don't, then it defeats the whole concept of deliveries, which are meant to be door to door. •People living in rougher areas would be unlikely to be served by these robots, as companies, like many taxi drivers now, would be unwilling to enter areas of risk. •If the robot stops for people, which they should, how, in a busy area, do they get anywhere without being stationary for half a trip. As far as I can see, these vehicles have a niche market, areas planned specifically for robots that overcome all of the problems that a contemporary city throws at them.

These are interesting sure, but I don’t see how they’re going to solve the US’ problem of car-oriented design. Places that are designed for cars aren’t going to become urban paradises because of delivery robots (Not to mention where would these robots even go on suburban or rural roads without sidewalks? Could they even travel the distances necessary to make deliveries in car-oriented neighborhoods?). Chances are these would be used in already urban neighborhoods with shorter delivery distances and existing sidewalks. But then, these neighborhoods are already at least somewhat walkable by definition. Adding delivery robots doesn’t add more pedestrian space or make a neighborhood more walkable.

Is this the future? Possibly. Is it worth it? I don’t think so. While we have UberEats and other food delivery services available, they aren’t really great. Mainly because of the human aspect of the delivery. 1) Delivery staff can take the money and call it a day while the customer gets nothing. The service may terminate the staff for failure to comply and theft. 2) Delivery order can be ridiculously small and not worth the trip like that order of Starbucks. Not saying for this device but for the delivery service that uses people. The driver can just simply decline. The order and it may be handed to another driver who may pick it up, ultimately forcing a driver to make the trip and delivering the small order that probably took a large portion of the profit for gas. 3) These delivery services are paid poorly. One might be fortunate to get a tip (if that’s how most services work) but I believe they just get a small delivery payment and the rest goes to the service which is really the sad part of these services. I believe that this will eventually replace human delivery drivers for those kinds of services as they are kind of better. Small, rechargeable, they look sturdy and are aware of their surroundings. Its the “ghetto” part of communities since they can be stolen and scavenged for parts. That is what worries me for these small buggers. Anyways, that’s just me and what I’ve seen in my community.

We are already operating commercially in 4 countries and we work very hard to ensure that our robots work seamlessly and share space respectfully alongside other people on the sidewalks. If one were to malfunction we have local teams who are able to respond immediately and pick up the robot to ensure it is not causing any blockages or obstruction. Thanks!

Hi Damien Spectre, we've never had one stolen - they have a number of anti-theft measures including a locked cargo hold (only the customer can unlock it using their smartphone), cameras, sirens, and GPS tracking. They are constantly supervised remotely by our staff in a control centre. As they have travelled hundreds of thousands of miles across many different cities they have experienced a few minor bumps and scrapes along the way but have never been in a serious accident with a third party. Surprisingly most of the people who encounter them actually ignore them, the ones who interact are usually very excited and intrigued. Thanks!

Have been successfully using Starship since early 2019 in Milton Keynes, UK’s fastest growing city. Starship provide a fabulous app with swift delivery of groceries from two different stores. It’s absolutely the way ahead for eco-friendly local deliveries. Best of all, it’s here now and now established as part of everyday life.

I liked Starship Tech's best. The only company thoughtful enough to alert pedestrians in heavily walked, and crowded intersections using a well placed flag. Whether or not we like it, we humans are somewhat like deers, who work best in a flat environment, and who tend to ignore "anomalies," that don't fit into our "flat space," especially when "maxed out" as in walking through a crowd in a heavily walked intersection. Just like the deer who is easily picked off by hunters in tree-stands, so to will pedestrians often stumble over a rolling beer cooler trying to navigate itself through a heavily walked intersection, with no eye-height flag. Which ever company is found to be best at meeting such human needs, will be found to be the most "needed" company. I agree with the Starship engineers, that attempts to fly merchandise overhead using the whirring blades of drones, totally ignores the very human need for safety from such overhead accidents waiting to happen. Sensible robots that are conscientiously designed with human safety first will take the day.

An important thing to note is that these robots and the technology required to make them end up doing a few things for human jobs. 1. Baseline, it creates jobs. These are new industries and emergent technologies that require humans to engineer, manufacture, and program these robots to do this kind of work. 2. As the creator stated, these robots are meant to optimize the human Dashers' job by letting them take the deliveries that pay them more as a result. Dashers often don't want to take the short 2-3 minute jobs because the pay is low, and the travel required on both ends to and from the delivery is actually costing them more than if they took a longer delivery. Also if you really want to use the robot jobs vs humans analogy, then you should be similarly upset at places like car manufacturing plants, where robots have taken human "jobs" for decades now (but that industry has not suffered as a result, nor have the types of jobs that only humans can do have changed and evolved over time). jimmy

So cute! But this is a real business. 95% of the time there will be NO customer ready to pop out and greet the bot at the moment of delivery. The FedEx Bot is the clear winner from my perspective. It has superior navigation skills, which are the hardest and most expensive piece for any bot. A SUPER requirement for delivering large/heavy boxes right up to someone's front door. A suitable bot must be able to navigate any and all kinds of surface terrain (dirt, small stones, crushed seashells) in any weather (rain/snow/ice) walking on possibly unclear paths and coming up against objects such as toys, landscaping bushes, flowers, deciding whether to try to clear the path or go around an object, then finally make its way down or up stairways/stairwells, irregular stone stairs, steep steps made of everything from slippery composite boards, to old/cracked/broken wood/concrete material, and position itself right up to that front or side door to drop the package in a manner that is safe. Small details such as whether the front door opens IN or opens OUT will determine whether any portion of the package can be left in the path of an OUTWARD swinging front door. The most common front door consists of a large cement set of 2 or 3 steps where the cement stairs is usually only a few inched wider than the door itself, making it dangerous or impossible to leave most large and/or heavy packages on the top landing of the front door cement steps IF the outermost front door opens OUTWARD, because it would hit the package and either push it off the stairs flying (if lightweight), or prevent the customer from coming out the front door to retreive their package (if package is heavy).

It's a great question. Some of the ways that delivery robot companies are addressing this are having the compartment locked until the customer unlocks it with their mobile app, and having cameras--and people--that are monitoring for theft or vandalism. It may also help that the devices at the moment just deliver food, so the hassle and risk of stealing and destroying one to get a free burrito (almost certainly cold by then...) may simply not be worth it. Time will tell, though!

Of course I am much stricter, because robots are far less than people. They are just sensors and actuators and a motherboard somewhere. A walking notebook. Of course I can use force to keep your robot from doing what it wants on my property. And of course you should be made to pay for the public space you use.

Ah but that opens up a whole other can of worms. You see, my right of way must never be blocked and a robot must never make physical contact with me or otherwise fire a projectile or emit anything that is injurious to me. That rules out pretty much every conceivable active countermeasure a robot might have, such as tasers, chemical sprays, high-decibel siren etc. Because even when I'm not the attacker, I could be a bystander who is affected. But also because your robot might not be welcome on my property and I'm expediting its departure. What if I'm hurt by your robot just because I am kicking it and shoving it out of my door? I think a lot of thought still has to go into this entire business of mixing humans with robots. Human safety is only the tip of the iceberg, there are many other issues as well. Such as how you will pay for the public space your robot or robots use? What insurances shall we require you to carry. What annual certifications will we require? Will you need an operator license?

I'm curious about that too. I envision a multi-faceted approach. Probably can't just be one thing. Sidewalk robots, flying drones, ziplines, and tubes or tunnels are all possibilities. Currently, the concern I have with the sidewalk robots is that they are probably only good for close-proximity delivery. If it is too far away it would take extra long to deliver and people aren't going to go for that. And if the location is walking distance from the home, then maybe, just maybe, the people should walk there anyway and pick it up! I know that's not always practical, but I'm thinking, if the robot was at the corner store near my apartment and I wanted some food from there, I would just prefer to walk there and get it. If I order delivery it is often when I'm already out driving, on my way home, and I pick something up on my way. If I'm already at home and the place I want delivery from is a good distance away, that's where a better method of fast-delivery would be welcomed. I think we also need sustainable delivery and return systems. That means, some standardization of containers so that when we get the product out of the box/container, we can put it back and it can be used by a variety of stores instead of just one 'brand'. Still don't know the quite, right mix, but I'm open to suggestion.

it’s a mixed bag, as a test driver, I see a lot of people breaking the law, running stop signs and other road violations. It would be funny/creepy if our company sent these people a photo or video link, like hey we saw, please do your best to drive safer haha. Since we are in San Francisco, I’ve been talking to my coworkers about anti-Asian hate crime, like what are we allowed to do if we see something, and the answer I got was it’s complicated, the company doesn’t want to be associated with even the idea of providing data to law enforcement. Now if we want to pull over and get involved/call the police, it’s our choice. However, we also haven’t been put in the position where we were witnesses in a hate crime, that I know of. Legislation forcing these companies to share data with the government, in my opinion would be overstepping the public’s trust. In terms of locating a missing person, like an elderly person with dementia or something I actually think it could be a positive/cool thing. It’s a slippery slope though. Autonomous ride share vehicles will be roaming cities in the future, and if they happen to witness a crime, much like cctv cameras do, law enforcement will need a warrant to access the footage, if they can prove the vehicle was near that location etc.

who owns the data depends on the company making them and if they have a contract with law enforcement. The company I work for, an autonomous vehicle company, has vowed not to share data with law enforcement. I’m pretty sure most autonomous companies share this same ideal, because public trust means everything to these companies.

The interesting aspect of all this is that the same "capitalists" that are pushing and supporting this automation movement fail to see that they are in fact sowing the demise of capitalism faster than any so called Marxist ever could. Silicon Valley knows this and it is why many industry tycoons have been quietly building bunkers and buying land in New Zealand, they fear they day society turns on them and realizes their suffering was brought on by these people and their agenda to wipe out 80% of all human labor. This speaks for itself, If all this tech was rooted in good and a noble ideal then whats is there to fear, why run to hide, why prepare for the wrath of society, unless you knowingly are working to hurt and take away peoples livelihood.

I'm not against delivery robots but we need a reality check like this. We're simply not ready and can not be ready for wide scale public use of robot delivery or policing robots unless possibly two conditions are met. There would need to be heavy fines (like Singapore justice) for tampering with them like with the Federal Mail or they would need to reach a status of essential service workers where people would respect them due to perhaps a fear of being on the streets with rising rates of disease or crime. The risks for simple willful damage to the robots is too great and too easy unless they had a self defense mechanism built in like an electronic tazer:). They could be victimized by any number of assailants such as simple practical jokers, competitive saboteurs, anti robot activists, run of the mill thieves and vandals etc. Even though they would be monitored by head office, the attackers would be gone in a matter of minutes. The easiest attack would be to simply throw one like a moped, into a pickup truck and into a Faraday non traceable bag. Vandals could simply throw a heavy sticky, ruglike material onto the robot, or pour some liquid like oil or cement onto the wheel mechanism. Other ways could be to smash them with some type of ramming object or vehicle or spray paint the camera lenses and sensors. Or the contents themselves could be rendered undeliverable by spraying the whole unit with some noxious skunk like smell and then derailing the whole public's trust in them. Sure we've had success with driverless vehicles as the general public is now at the early fascination stage of most robotic assistance devices. This probably won't last too long unless the public sees these robots as essential for modern day living.

You're definitely right that most cities and HOAs currently wouldn't allow something like this right away. It'll be interesting to see how it - and cities - evolve in the coming years. After all, things like cars were not allowed universally at first, and more recently ridesharing services were banned in many cities before, often, gradually gaining acceptance (though they currently have their own financial issues). It may depend on customers and businesses wanting them. If it's thought of as simply more traffic with no utility to you, it's not a very exciting prospect. But if it enables you to get great food quickly and cheaply, or allows your business to sell way more products, it could be quite popular. If it reaches the point where there are tons of vehicles, it may be necessary to come up with a new solution. There's a lot of cities that are currently redesigning their roads to allow micromobility (bike/scooter/etc) lanes, so perhaps they could share those or have dedicated delivery lanes in crowded areas.

Hi. Regards from Finland. Very interesting video. I have seen one and made a short video of it recently. It was nice and friendly, because it slowed down when it reached us. This happened when we returned from our food shopping tour. We are an old couple which walk twice a week for food shopping. The round trip is about 4.0 km / 2.49 mi long. We both have a backpack on our back and one bag in our hand. Sometimes I have two bags, meaning that I have one bag in both hands. Why we walk for shopping? It is very natural. It keeps in a good condition! No need to go to the gym. Sometimes we add an additional longer route for shopping. In winter, when the temperature is about -24°C / -11°F, We walk also - naturally. Can you imagine if we have cold? No, not at all, because we are carrying heavy food loads with us. This means that after walking about half of our trip, we are starting to sweat. The big question is, of course, if would we like to change our shopping habits to a robot? Of course not, because we will maintain our physical condition in the current way. So natural! Matti

no its not a load of rubbish about the shortage of drivers at all... Its fact! Whether someone doesn't want to drive because of poor pay or long hours is completely irrelevant. The fact still remains that there is a shortage regardless of the reason. It makes no difference if you are or were a lorry driver, if you don't want to do it any more then you no longer are one. We are 100,000 drivers short in the UK alone fact so you moaning to me for listening to the media is just rubbish. Where else am i going to get the news from "truckers digest" . And going on about how drivers can make 50k a year but by doing 60 hours a week means nothing to me as my last job was 60+ hours a week for only 30k... Irrelevant point! My original points were that A) there is a shortage of drivers (regardless of why) and B) British people just don't want to do the work, same as fruit picking etc. So what do we have to do, rely on bringing in foreign workers because without them our country will be screwed.

Isn’t it ironic that now truck drivers are in short supply that everyone is falling over themselves to try and make our life better, Why ! Because it’s affecting the general public’s way of life, Well here’s some of the reasons why you the public can’t get your precious McDonald’s milk shake or your favourite bottle of beer from the Supermarket, For decades the majority of hauliers have suppressed the wages of drivers, expecting a 60 to 70 hour working week for a take home pay of around the £500 to £600 mark, For decades the well-being of most drivers have never been taking into consideration, asking for the simple things like a fridge or even a night heater in the truck would result in the company saying, Well if you don’t like it you know where the door is, we can soon replace you, Most hauliers ( not all ) still expect us to do 3 x 15 hours days on the trot with a measly 9 hours off, that’s 45 hours of work in 3 days and yes it’s legal for us to do that, That’s more than you the general public do all week, Fancy a bit if that do you ? I think not, Asking to get home for a reason would often result in them giving you an impossible task on that day, A lot of hauliers even to this day won’t pay for overnight parking in a truck stop or a Motorway Services because of the cost of parking that’s in the region of £20 to £40 a night that’s why we have to park in a lay-by or an industrial estate with no facilities for the driver for 9 to 11 hours so when you the general public unfortunately stumble across a driver having a piss, don’t knock him for doing a natural bodily function that you can do in the comfort of your home, As for delivering / collecting from customers, A lot of the time we are late, not our fault most of the time but we get the flack so we feel that we have to go cap in hand to try and get tipped but often met with YOUR LATE ! you’ll have to wait until we can fit you in or you’ll have to get it re-booked, Well sorry old pal but you should be fucking grateful that you’ve actually got your stuff here, not give us attitude because we have upset your 8 hour shift routine, As for actually driving a 44 tonne truck, Why oh why nowadays do you the car driver on a 70 mph road with good driving conditions sit there at 50 to 55 mph getting tangled up with us trucks that are limited to 56 mph You shouldn’t be anywhere near us, we shouldn’t be catching you up like we seem to nowadays, We shouldn’t be put in a situation to have to overtake you, you shouldn’t be anywhere to be seen, so when you sit behind us in the overtaking lane, annoyed because I’m holding you up the chances are that I’m overtaking a twat in a car who think the A64 is a country lane to bumble along on, so swear at him not us, Overall this is just the tip of the iceberg of what’s wrong with this haulage industry, I could go on forever with what needs changing, Why do I still do it ? Because it’s in my blood, it’s a part of my life, I still have passion for the job that’s why, but rest assured it’s going to get worse as the average age of a truck driver is 55 years old now and rising, I personally don’t think this is a Brexit thing, this is all down to decades of suppression of the HGV driver by the hauliers, basically treating us like shit, You the hauliers have put yourselves in this situation and I’m glad to see that it’s come back to bite you lot on the arse.

Owen I’m a lorry driver myself and I can quite clearly see your listening to the media. It is a load of rubbish about the shortage of drivers.. the truth is there is a shortage of drivers that are willing to drive for rubbish money. There’s a shortage of company’s willing to pay a decent wage and are more interested in the profit.. where do you think the higher wages are coming from now? It’s not because companies can’t afford it. £12 an hour to drive and have the responsibility of a 44ton truck? All your driving times are highly regulated often with numerous rules contradicting each other. Anything that could possibly go wrong is the drivers fault and the driver will be held accountable. Who would want that for such rubbish money? You may also see on the news ‘truck drivers earn really good money’. Yes we earn £40-50k a year but the amount and the irregular hours(often 3-4am starts) we work makes that wage a pittance. Truck drivers are expected to work on average 60hours a week + nights out (away from family and friends) at the same time the ‘planners’ in the office are work 9am-5pm earn the same money as us and have a company car.. what would you rather do? Have a job with a late start time and reasonable finish time? Or a job which has really early starts and no finish time.. treated and spoken to like rubbish from planers same at your delivery/collection points.. public in cars causing havoc which can make the difference of you getting home or not.. sitting at deliveries for 6 hours for no reason.. sitting on the docks waiting for your container for 3 hours.. what would you rather do? Drivers have been on the same wage for over 15years at the same time other careers the wages have doubled. Drivers ask for a pay rise and all that gets said is if drivers get a pay rise the cost of everything will go up for everyone.. do you hear lorry drivers complaining that the gas engineer has had a pay rise so we have to pay more for our gas servicing? No you don’t. To tell someone to wise up is hardly attacking someone it’s a fact. Maybe you should stop worrying about your McDonald’s milkshake and find out the truth and see what’s happening for yourself rather than listening to the rubbish the media and the rich hauliers are telling you.

These robots are not designed in-house as Amazon claims, but a a re-skinned robot by a company named Starship Enterprises: https://www.starship.xyz/ IPR lawyers are pretty busy somewhere when you read this I guess. There are more reasons to buy Papa Johns stock than ever now: 1. Papa Johns is targetting insiders for automation which are the hardest to staff and easiest to replace 2. People who don't like call centers and robots from Pizza Hut and Dominoes make up 10% of Papa Johns Sales 3. Nearly 100% of customers routinely claim they will not order from a store that does not physically up to the door. Many live in dorms, hotel rooms condos, apartments, and other robot unfriendly places 4. As a P/T weekend driver, I know that I use my phone to contact someone who is unreachable by any other mechanism 33% - 50% of the time out of 20-30 deliveries a night 5. As that driver. 15% of my deliveries involve improper addresses. Another 5% might involve other creative means to reach the customer 6. Another (very little intersection here) 5-10% of customers want to complain if things are not 100% correct and want a solution to that problem even if they did not create the issue 7. Driving at the speed required to make a delivery requires bending rules (not breaking them) and getting a little creative with routes. As a data architect/developer/programmer with quite a few CS courses under my belt, I know humans can and will for some time outperform robots in this aspect. Pizza Hut royally messed up customers with 30 minutes or less and actually got people killed (they lost a lawsuit over it). It takes 20 minutes to get your order out. 8. Papa Johns will probably not replace drivers anytime soon as it tends to be a laggard technologically Essentially, people are willing to pay a premium for 2-7 (tips average about $3.50 per delivery in my area and trend from $2-$4 in every area). However, if they don't get 2-7 they leave for somewhere else. A store that refuses them even in part tends to lose up to 40% of sales within 6-8 mths. Even if your customer service drops slightly, you lose 30% of your sales. Wrong industry for this sort of automation. Now, there is also a reason to buy FedEx and Walmart stock. Who cares how a package is delivered as long as it is intact and timely enough. FedEx, UPS, and long haul anything are about to croak. CSR jobs performed over a distance at speed, not so much.

Car food delivery can’t be profitable with a human driving or a 2000 pound plus vehicle, even if it is autonomous, to carry a sandwich. It’s too much labor and energy for too little product. The food delivery companies all loose money. Eventually they have to switch to light silly delivery vehicles before investors get tired of pouring money into companies that have no way to make money.

It's self-driving at level 4 that solves it, not this particular implementation. The point is that once you have safe operation at level 4, able to run reliably and hands-off within a predefined zone - and that's not far off, since there are plenty of examples of such services achieving deployments - changing the form factor of the vehicle is a small detail that just means retraining it to follow rules appropriate to its size and type of cargo. If you can run a delivery robot, you can run a robobike; if you can run a robotaxi, you can run a robobus. If you can run a robobus, you can run a robotruck. And they can get the cost down with economics of scale, making it cheaper to rent than to buy these vehicles; at minimum you'll be able to access exactly the capacity you need, rather than buying and maintaining for your peak load(which leads to roads filled with one passenger in a car that seats four or six). In lower density you'll have more single-seat options, in dense areas, more buses. So it is not just delivery but all road traffic that shifts towards shared on-demand fleets in an instant, just like how smartphones suddenly took off after the iPhone. In effect, everyone in the future is a transit user, save a few folks who either want a luxury vehicle or are too rural to be part of the networks. And then the consequences go on from there; a shrinking need for parking, easier point-to-point services shifting optimal sites for commercial construction, and so on.

Meet the autonomous delivery robots which are shaping the future of food delivery. Starship A six-wheeled ground drone from Starship Technologies. Equipped with a sensor suite that includes cameras, GPS and inertial measurement units, the robot can deliver items within a 6km radius. It has a large compartment to hold deliveries equivalent to the size of two grocery bags with a maximum weight of 10kg. Once the robot has arrived at the customer, the compartment is opened using a unique code generated after placing the order from a smartphone app. In March 2017, Dominos entered into a partnership with Starship Technologies to use the latter's robots as "personal delivery devices" The company plans to distribute thousands of robots across campuses around the world by 2019. Kiwi Kiwi is an autonomous delivery robot that picks up and delivers food and personal-care items within a roughly 1.6 square kilometers area centered around campus. The robot uses Deep Learning to correctly interpret data gathered from its sensors and to make intelligent decisions that ensure a fast, safe and cost-efficient delivery. It can correctly identify traffic lights in order to cross streets and detect objects and obstacles to avoid collisions in a safe, reliable manner. Robomart Robomart, a literally little mini-mart on wheels. It is engineered with cutting-edge technology, including driverless tech for autonomy and teleoperations, an RFID and computer vision-based checkout-free system, and purpose-built refrigeration and temperature control. The bots are now used by Grocery store chain, Stop & Shop to deliver groceries to its customers. When customers want to buy some groceries, they simply tap a button in a smartphone app to request the nearest robomart. Once it arrives, they head outside, unlock the doors, and pick the products they want. Robomart tracks what customers have taken using patent-pending "grab and go" checkout-free technology and will charge them and send a receipt accordingly. TeleRetail Robot Using artificial intelligence to automate local logistics and minimize the ecological footprint of transportation, TeleRetail wants to help Main Street shops and small businesses to compete with major e-commerce companies like Amazon. The robot is made by the Swiss startup TeleRetail founded in 2014 by Torsten Scholl with the aim of solving the logistical problems of local businesses. With its 84 centimeter width and capability to carry up to 35 kilograms payloads, the robot is designed to travel on sidewalks, covering long distances up to about 80 kilometers Amazon Scout Entering the race of autonomous delivery robots is nonother than the e-commerce giant, Amazon. Amazon Scout, a six-wheeled self-driving delivery machine that is "the size of a small cooler". Walking at a human pace, Scout uses self-driving technology to navigate through neighborhoods to deliver packages to Amazon Prime Customers. The vehicle appears large enough to accommodate small and medium-sized parcels, but no word yet on what's under the hood. FedEx SameDay Bot So far, FedEx SameDay Bot is the latest of a long line of last-mile delivery robots that transport small packages from shops or local distribution centers directly to consumers. FedEx says it will refine it, and then begin deployment as soon as the company’s engineers are satisfied with its performance. The bot is being developed by FedEx in collaboration with DEKA Development & Research Corp., the company behind mobility device iBot. It features pedestrian-safe tech, multiple cameras, Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) and machine learning to help it detect and avoid obstacles, and navigate uneven surfaces. Updates: Domino pizza chain announced that it has entered into a partnership with Nuro, a robotics delivery startup, to test using its robots to transport pizzas from a store in Houston.
